诗人出身的民兵领导人貌桑卡是缅甸争取民主的最著名人物之一，他表示，他的武装组织计划开始在该国的中心地带开辟领土，以更直接地对抗军政府。

Maung Saungkha 表示，此举是他的缅族人民解放军 (BPLA) 的一个关键战略目标。BPLA 是军政府 2021 年 2 月政变后组建的民兵组织，现在已经获得了盟友的训练和该国边境的战斗经验。大多数缅甸人民解放军成员都是信奉佛教的缅族，该族群占人口三分之二，在政府机构所在地缅甸中部占主导地位。

这位 30 岁的指挥官在靠近泰国边境的丛林营地发短信说：“对于一支由缅族人组成的军队来说，驻扎缅族地区并在那里活跃是我们愿景的重要组成部分。”

芒桑卡表示，人民解放军希望与人民国防军合作，这是民族团结政府的武装派系，由昂山素季政府的残余势力组成，旨在取代军政府。人民国防军由数百名民兵组成，其中大部分是缅族人。

总部位于缅甸的战略与政策研究所估计，人民解放军约有 1,000 名成员，这一数字将使其成为该国最大的新民兵组织之一。

一名重要盟友和两名分析人士表示，人民解放军的发展很大程度上归功于 Maung Saungkha 与其他武装团体建立联系的能力。它还突显了新的民兵组织如何在缅甸的政治格局中根深蒂固，尽管它们距离推翻军政府还很远。

为人民解放军提供部分粮食支持的民族团结政府表示，为了集中重建人民解放军的基地，人民解放军必须与其国防部进行谈判，以确保与人民国防军的顺利合作。

军政府没有回应对本文发表评论的请求。报告称，反对该计划的武装团体是“恐怖分子”，他们制造混乱并杀害平民。正如它对其统治的大多数反对者所做的那样，它指控貌桑卡煽动叛乱。

Maung Saungkha 和 BPLA 的政治官员 Yoe Aunt Min 表示，与军政府的斗争将是漫长的，并承认 BPLA 面临重大挑战 - 特别是资金和一些新兵继续战斗的动力减弱。

缅族的主导地位长期以来一直受到缅甸许多少数民族的不满，但貌桑卡的背景帮助缅甸人民解放军与其他少数民族武装组织建立了牢固的联系，这项微妙的工作被视为对抵抗运动至关重要。

政变之前，他是一位诗人，因一首讽刺权威的诗句而入狱，后来成为一位备受瞩目的活动家，倡导少数族裔平等和联邦制。

智库危机组织的缅甸高级顾问理查德·霍西表示，这一记录赋予了缅甸人民解放军“意识形态影响力”。

从 BB 枪到 AK-81

缅甸边境政变两个月后，缅甸人民解放军成立，貌桑卡寻求民族武装组织的培训和支持，这些组织几十年来一直在争取更大的自治权。

Maung Saungkha 表示，最初，BPLA 训练时只有木枪和 BB 枪，但现在他们拥有一些 M16 步枪和 AK-81 步枪，并向盟友借用了其他武器。

他说，BPLA 与其所在地的克伦民族联盟 (KNU) 以及提供训练的若开军 (AA) 密切合作。

两个团体都证实，人民解放军正在与他们的部队并肩作战。

澳大利亚国立大学缅甸研究中心分析师尼古拉·威廉姆斯表示，抵抗力量对军政府造成了重大损害，并夺取了领土。

但她说，为了产生更大的影响，他们需要超越在城市地区制造混乱和混乱的范围，并共同努力夺取战略要地，并补充说，他们的努力因武装团体之间对武器和资源的竞争而受到阻碍。

AA副总司令Nyo Tun Aung准将在给路透社的一封信中表示，Maung Saungkha与“民族革命组织”的领导人建立了“良好而密切的关系”。

Nyo Tun Aung 写道，BPLA 通过发展“同样的革命心跳”赢得了支持。

尤阿姨敏说，许多民兵在缅族占多数的地区活动，这意味着人民解放军无法轻易在那里活跃起来，但它有多种选择。

她说，除了与国防军合作外，还可以派遣小型无人机操作部队。

“我们还收到了培训其他人的请求，所以我们可能会从培训师开始，”她补充道。

资金和士气问题

Maung Saungkha 表示，尽管 BPLA 得到了盟友在食品和其他物资方面的支持，但资金问题一直是一个令人担忧的问题。

据联合国毒品和犯罪问题办公室称，一些武装族裔团体长期依赖贩毒获取资金。但 BPLA 表示，其唯一的独立资金来自捐赠、BPLA 品牌连帽衫和商品的销售以及 Maung Saungkha 的诗集。路透社无法独立证实这一点。

相比之下，据联合国称，中国和俄罗斯为军政府提供武器，并指责缅甸军事统治者对任意空袭、大规模屠杀和法外处决负有责任。军政府表示正在对“恐怖分子”采取合法行动。

貌桑卡 (Maung Saungkha) 拒绝透露他的团队中有多少成员，他说，经过两年的战争，一些士兵因为想家、无聊和疲惫而逃跑了。

“今年，短暂的革命者将赶回家......现在只是预选赛阶段。前面还有很多战斗，”他说。

Shoon Naing 和 Poppy McPherson 报道；埃德温娜·吉布斯编辑; Fri, 04 Aug 2023 01:08:53 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/myanmar-poet-turned-rebel-leader-seeks-new-territory-worries-about-ephemeral-2023-08-04/ https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/myanmar-poet-turned-rebel-leader-seeks-new-territory-worries-about-ephemeral-2023-08-04/Shoon Naing, Poppy Mcpherson缅甸冲突/叛乱领袖（PIX、电视、图形） Superconductor claims spark investor frenzy, but scientists are skeptical

上周，韩国科学家发表的两篇论文提出了一个非凡的主张，引发了社交媒体的狂热，并推高了中国和韩国一些股票的价格：发现了一种实用的超导体。

超导体是一种允许电流无阻力流动的材料，这种特性将彻底改变电网（在传输过程中会损失能量），以及先进的领域，例如计算芯片（其中电阻充当速度限制）。

这些论文出现在科学家们在正式同行评审和发表之前分享研究成果的网站上，促使世界各地的研究人员——包括至少两个美国国家实验室和三所中国大学的研究人员——仔细研究拟议的材料。

超导材料已经存在于医学成像核磁共振机和一些量子计算机等领域，但仅在极低的温度下才能显示出超导特性，这使得它们无法广泛使用。

韩国研究人员上周表示，他们发现了一种在室温下工作的超导体，长期以来，这一直被认为是该领域科学家的圣杯。

研究人员还发布了一种制造这种材料的配方，称为 LK-99，其中包括采用一种相对常见的矿物铅磷灰石，并向其中引入少量铜原子。

韩国研究人员发表了两篇论文——一篇是由三名作者组成的初始论文，另一篇是由六名作者组成的更详细的论文，其中仅包括第一篇论文中的两名作者。路透社联系的所有作者都没有回应置评请求。

接受路透社采访的物理学家表示，好消息是，没有物理定律表明室温超导体不可能存在，而且韩国团队描述的材料很容易生长，这意味着其他研究人员应该能够开始获得如下结果：最快本周。

发现证明的黄金标准是其他实验室可靠地复制韩国研究人员的发现。

至少三所中国大学的研究人员最近几天表示，他们生产了不同版本的 LK-99，但结果各不相同。华中科技大学的一个团队发布了一段视频，声称展示了材料悬浮在磁铁上，这很重要，因为真正的超导体可以以任何方向漂浮在磁铁上，而不会像指南针一样旋转。

但曲阜师范大学的另一个团队表示，他们没有观察到零电阻，而这是超导体所需的特性之一。第三位来自中国东部城市南京东南大学的一位人士表示，他们测量到的电阻为零，但温度仅为 110 开尔文（-163 摄氏度）。

周四，韩国专家表示，他们将成立一个委员会来核实这些说法。

埃里克·图恩 (Eric Toone) 是比尔·盖茨 (Bill Gates) 突破能源风险投资公司 (Breakthrough Energy Ventures) 的一名科学家出身的投资者，他表示，他正在监控信誉良好的实验室的任何同行评审和复制工作。

图恩说：“验证或证明超导性所需的测量非常困难。” “如果它是正确的，这将彻底改变游戏规则，但在我们得到更多验证之前，我们必须保持耐心。”

“你可能会被愚弄”

对于 LK-99 来说，可能的坏消息是，超导领域充满了起初很有希望但在仔细审查下就会崩溃的材料。研究人员甚至给它们起了一个方便的名字——不明超导物体。

“我们称它们为 USO，”阿贡国家实验室的凝聚态物理学家迈克·诺曼说。 “USO 的历史可以追溯到很久以前，包括一些非常著名的人，他们认为自己拥有超导体，但他们没有。这就像科学中的任何事情一样 - 你可能会被愚弄。即使是好人也可能被愚弄。”

诺曼说原来的论文有问题。有些可能是由于急于发表研究而造成的印刷错误，但更令人不安的是缺乏广泛温度范围内的数据来显示材料在处于超导状态和非超导状态时的行为。

“人们经常使用这种方法来显示样品中有多少实际上是超导体，有多少不是，”诺曼说。

其他研究人员也找到了需要谨慎的理由。固态物理学家兼劳伦斯伯克利国家实验室科学家西尼德·格里芬 (Sinéad Griffin) 使用美国能源部的超级计算机来模拟所提出的材料。

格里芬发现，将铜原子插入铅磷灰石中会导致该材料的原子以一种意想不到的方式重新排列，类似于现有的超导体。但这种效应取决于铜原子是否会到达它们自然不想去的位置，这可能会使批量生产该材料变得更加困难。

格里芬警告说，她的模拟有局限性——它不能最终证明该材料是超导体，而且这项工作假设研究人员可以以完美的精度将铜原子放入铅磷灰石中。在现实世界中，这种情况不太可能发生，并且可能会对材料产生很大影响。

澳大利亚墨尔本莫纳什大学物理学教授迈克尔·富勒 (Michael Fuhrer) 表示，即使 LK-99 确实成为室温超导体，仍需要时间来确定它的用途。例如，Fuhrer 表示，没有提供有关该材料能够承载多少电流并且仍然是超导体的数据，这是改善电网的关键问题。

尽管如此，富勒和其他物理学家表示，考虑到有关超导体的一切仍然未知，以及超导体可能在普通材料中偶然发现的可能性，这些结果仍然值得研究。

“那里有很多很多的矿物我们还没有研究过，”阿贡国家实验室的诺曼说。 “这些矿物中可能隐藏着一些非常有趣的物理原理。”

总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基周四谴责了在对乌克兰征兵中心进行审计期间暴露的“令人反感”的做法，并承诺通过任命了解战争含义的人来负责修复该系统。

黑海港口敖德萨发生一起备受瞩目的不当行为事件后，泽连斯基对上个月审计中发现的腐败行为表示愤慨。

泽伦斯基在会见内政部长伊霍尔·克利缅科和 SBU 安全部门负责人瓦西里·马留克后，在夜间视频讲话中表示：“我们进行了详细的交谈。”

泽伦斯基说：“调查揭露了许多滥用职权的行为。” “坦率地说，他们是令人反感的。”

对招聘办公室的调查是长期根除腐败运动的一部分，在乌克兰推动加入北约和欧盟的运动中，腐败是一个关键问题。

泽连斯基表示，所有调查结果都将公开，并接受刑事诉讼。

“结论很明确：招募系统需要了解保护乌克兰价值的人，”他说。

“招募中心的工作人员必须是见过战争、经历过战争的人，”他补充道。 “可悲的是，那些人可能失去了四肢，但没有失去尊严，也没有失去乌克兰。让我感谢他们。”

敖德萨一个征兵中心的负责人被指控腐败和贪污，上个月被下令审前拘留。

该官员被指控在没有解释的情况下获取了相当于略高于 500 万美元的资金。乌克兰媒体报道称，他的家人在西班牙购买了房产。

罗恩·波佩斯基报道。格里·多伊尔编辑; Thu, 03 Aug 2023 23:55:22 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraines-zelenskiy-decries-revolting-practices-recruitment-centres-2023-08-03/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraines-zelenskiy-decries-revolting-practices-recruitment-centres-2023-08-03/Reuters乌克兰危机/招聘 Florida effectively bans advanced psychology course over LGBTQ content, course developer says

开发课程的非营利组织周四表示，佛罗里达州已告知学校负责人，向高中生提供的先修心理学课程违反了该州禁止性取向和性别认同教学的新法律，实际上禁止了该课程。

这是共和党州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯 (Ron DeSantis) 政府限制该州有关 LGBTQ 问题和种族问题的最新举措。德桑蒂斯正在挑战美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普，争夺 2024 年共和党总统候选人提名，并将文化问题之争作为其竞选的核心内容。

佛罗里达州今年早些时候禁止了一门新的AP 非裔美国人研究课程，称其缺乏“教育价值和历史准确性”，并违反​​了州关于如何在公共课堂教授种族的法律。

虽然佛罗里达州官员表示，如果修改以符合法律，心理学课程仍然可以提供，但负责开发 AP 课程的大学理事会建议学区暂时不要教授该课程，而不是提供没有性内容的材料。取向和性别认同。

该组织周四在其网站上发布的一份声明中表示：“需要明确的是，在佛罗里达州教授的任何 AP 心理学课程都将违反佛罗里达州法律或大学要求。” “因此，我们建议佛罗里达州学区不要提供 AP 心理学，直到佛罗里达州改变决定并允许家长和学生选择参加完整课程。”

佛罗里达州教育部发言人周四否认该州已按照大学理事会的说法禁止心理学课程，该机构开发了帮助高中生获得大学学分的 AP 课程。

教育部发言人卡桑德拉·帕莱利斯 (Cassandra Palelis) 表示：“就在开学前一周，大学理事会正试图迫使学区阻止学生参加 AP 心理学课程。”

“我们鼓励大学理事会停止与佛罗里达州学生玩游戏，继续提供课程并允许教师进行相应操作。”

帕莱利斯没有立即回答有关该州是否已告知主管该课程违反州法律的问题。

大学理事会在其网站上发布的一封来自佛罗里达州的信显示，州政府和大学理事会之间关于心理学课程的讨论于五月开始。

在信中，该州提醒该组织注意其新法律禁止在除健康课程之外的所有课程中教授性取向和性别认同，家长可以选择不送孩子参加这些课程。

这封信要求大学理事会审核其课程材料，并修改任何不符合州法律或州教育委员会制定的规则的内容。

美国大学理事会周四表示，以这种方式修改其课程将使他们没有资格获得大学学分，并且也违反学术标准。

莎朗·伯恩斯坦报道；科琳·詹金斯和理查德·张编辑; Thu, 03 Aug 2023 23:03:23 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/florida- effectively-bans-advanced-psychology-course-over-lgbtq-content-course-2023-08-03/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/florida- effectively-bans-advanced-psychology-course-over-lgbtq-content-course-2023-08-03/Sharon Bernstein美国佛罗里达/教育 (PIX) California fire scorching precious Joshua trees

今年迄今为止加州最大的野火烧毁了珍贵的约书亚树，约书亚树曾经是土著人民编织篮子和凉鞋的重要文化象征，现在仍然是莫哈韦沙漠生态系统的重要组成部分。

卡尔菲尔表示，约克大火已在加州和内华达州边境附近烧毁约 94,000 英亩（38,000 公顷）土地，截至周四，34% 的面积已得到控制。

这场大火破坏了多样化的生态系统，并杀死了数量不详的约书亚树，这也因 U2 1987 年发行的专辑《约书亚树》而享誉国际。

大火烧焦了莫哈韦国家保护区，但尚未进入更著名的约书亚树国家公园，该公园距离约 60 英里（100 公里），每年接待约 300 万游客。莫哈韦国家保护区接待的游客数量还不到其三分之一。

A federal judge on Thursday rejected a gun rights group's challenge to an assault weapons ban the state of Connecticut adopted after an armed gunman in 2012 killed 20 children and six educators at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown.

The National Association for Gun Rights filed a lawsuit in September, arguing the 2013 ban violated the right to bear arms under the US Constitution's Second Amendment, citing a major US Supreme Court ruling last year that expanded gun rights.

That decision, New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. Bruen, was issued by the court's 6-3 conservative majority and held the Second Amendment protects a person's right to carry a handgun in public for self-defense.

The decision also announced a new test to assess the legality of gun restrictions, saying they must be "consistent with this nation's historical tradition of firearm regulation." NAGR said Connecticut's law failed to meet that standard.

But US District Judge Janet Bond Arterton in New Haven in a 74-page ruling rejected those claims, saying the group failed to establish that assault weapons and large capacity magazines are commonly bought and used for self-defense.

Arterton, an appointee of former Democratic President Bill Clinton, cited "persuasive" evidence by the state that assault weapons are instead more often sought out for their militaristic characteristics and are often used in crimes and mass shootings.

"The Nation has a longstanding history and tradition of regulating those aspects of the weapons or manners of carry that correlate with rising firearm violence," she said, and Connecticut's ban is "consistent with that purpose."

The National Association for Gun Rights did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Connecticut Attorney General William Tong, a Democrat whose office defended the ban in court, in a statement said the ruling "affirms that Connecticut's assault weapon and large capacity magazine bans remain on strong legal footing after the US Supreme Court decision in Bruen."

The United States would continue to do "whatever is necessary" to ensure Russia can freely export food if there was a revival of a deal allowing the safe Black Sea export of Ukrainian grain, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Thursday.

Russia last month quit the July 2022 deal brokered by the United Nations and Turkey aimed at easing a global food crisis after Russia's invasion of Ukraine five months earlier. Ukraine and Russia are both leading grain exporters.

"In the event of return to the agreement, of course, we'll continue to do whatever is necessary to make sure that everyone can export their food and food products freely and safely to include Russia," Blinken told reporters at the United Nations.

"We want to see that food on world markets. We want everyone to benefit from the lower prices," he said afterchairing a UN Security Council meeting on food insecurity caused by conflict.

Many countries at the gathering expressed disappointment that Russia had quit the deal and urged them to reconsider.

To convince Russia to agree to the Black Sea deal, another pact was also struck in July 2022 under which UN officials agreed to help Russia get its food and fertilizer exports to foreign markets.

While Russian exports of food and fertilizer are not subject to Western sanctions imposed after Russia's February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Moscow has said restrictions on payments, logistics and insurance have hindered shipments.

During the Security Council meeting on Thursday, Russia's Deputy UN Ambassador Dmitry Polyanskiy accused Western countries of an "arrogant unwillingness" to help fulfill the UN pact with Moscow.

He stressed that Russia held a larger share of the global wheat market than Ukraine and was a key fertilizer exporter.

"Western countries need to focus on ensuring that Russian grain and fertilizers can get to countries in need without hindrance," Polyanskiy said.

PRICING PRESSURES

Blinken told reporters that Russia's exports of food have exceeded levels prior to its invasion of Ukraine.

"Having said that, to the extent that there have been any problems with things like shipping and insurance, we have throughout the process of the Black Sea Grant initiative, taken steps to work through them and to address them," he said.

This included writing comfort letters to banks "to assure them that it was fine to process these transactions and that they wouldn't run afoul of our sanctions," Blinken said.

US bank JPMorgan (JPM.N) has processed some Russian grain export payments with reassurances from Washington.

The United Nations has argued that the Black Sea deal helped everyone because it brought prices down 23% from a record high in the weeks following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

After Moscow quit the deal, it began targeting Ukrainian ports and grain infrastructure on the Black Sea and Danube River, sending global grain prices soaring. Moscow has said it may resurrect the Black Sea agreement if its demands to improve its own exports of grain and fertilizer are met.

"If all the problems that have been publicly raised by us ... are eliminated, we will be ready to once again take part in the Black Sea initiative," Polyanskiy reiterated.

The European Union has warned developing countries that Russia is offering cheap grain "to create new dependencies by exacerbating economic vulnerabilities and global food insecurity," according to a letter seen by Reuters on Wednesday.

The Cuban Central Bank issued rules this week banning state and private businesses from using ATMs and limiting cash transactions between them, as it seeks to tame runaway inflation and off-the-books business amid a grave economic crisis.

The regulations went into effect on Thursday. They limit cash transactions to 5000 pesos and will be implemented gradually over six months, official media said.

The government pegs the dollar at 24 pesos and for select companies, tourists and residents at 120 pesos, though it has few to exchange. The dollar currently fetches 230 pesos on the informal market. Communist authorities are seeking to curb galloping inflation which the government puts at 45% so far this year and control the devaluation of the peso by taking a series of measures to promote "banking" in the country and encourage the use of "electronic payments", said a statement published on Thursday in the official media.

Inflation stood at 39% last year, and more than 70% in 2021, according to the government - figures many economists say underestimate the rate as they do not adequately account for a ballooning informal market.

Economy Minister Alejandro Gil said late last month gross domestic product grew 1.8% in the first half of the year, but remained 8 percentage points below pre-pandemic levels in 2019, causing shortages of food, medicine, fuel and other basic goods, as well as long lines to buy them when they are available.

The crisis has led to a lack of confidence in the state-run banking system, resulting in a lack of cash at some ATMs as businesses use them, leaving residents in the lurch.

The regulations state the objective is that "collections and payments between economic actors are not on a cash basis ... but carried out electronically.”

Justin Trudeau's surprise announcement that he and his wife were separating, just a week after a broad cabinet reshuffle, underscores the Canadian prime minister's focus and intent to lead the Liberal Party into a fourth election victory, despite sagging opinion polls, pollsters and insiders said.

On Wednesday, Trudeau and his wife Sophie Gregoire Trudeau unexpectedly announced their separation , likely marking the end of their 18-year-long high profile marriage. The separation is one of Trudeau's biggest personal crises, although insiders and political commentators said he wants to ride out the aftershocks.

"He's running again," said a source close to Trudeau, when asked whether the news of the separation might be prompting second thoughts. The source was not authorized to speak about the matter publicly.

Trudeau said on Instagram that the couple took the decision after "many meaningful and difficult conversations." His office said the two had signed a legal agreement and the couple would focus on raising their children.下周一家人将一起去度假。

Trudeau, 51, has always stressed the importance of family, and he and his wife were seen on campaign trails during elections, with his children by his side after three successive wins starting in 2015.

While the next election is only due by October 2025, Trudeau's campaign by all accounts will look different.

"The shuffle was a political clearing of the decks and this is a sort of personal clearing of the decks ... he seems determined to stay on as leader of the Liberal Party," said Roderick Phillips, history professor at Ottawa's Carleton University.

SHAKE-UP

Surveys of public opinion show voters are starting to tire of Trudeau, and last week's cabinet reshuffle was designed to build up his core economic team in response to cost-of-living challenges that Canadians have grappled with for more than two years.

Nik Nanos of polling firm Nanos Research said the separation, at the height of Canadian summer when few people are paying attention, cast a new light on a cabinet shuffle where several promising ministers received big promotions.

"This cabinet was likely made with a sensitivity to manage key files while Trudeau spends more time focused on his family," he said by email.

Trudeau's father, former Liberal prime minister Pierre Trudeau, also separated from his wife Margaret - known popularly as Maggie - when in office. The split occurred in 1977 and he lost an election in 1979 before bouncing back to win power again in 1980.

"The separation of Maggie and Pierre is an interesting historical antecedent but I don't think there was any clear connection to the present situation nor is there any clear causal link to his loss," Frank Graves, head of polling form EKOS, said.

"If it had damaged him politically it is hard to explain how he (Pierre) achieved another majority government the next year,” he added.

Graves said the news of Trudeau's separation was unlikely to have "much if any discernible impact on the voter landscape”.

Toronto resident Denise Davison, 60, said she believed the separation had no bearing on Trudeau's ability to be an effective prime minister.

"Actually, if he's going to be in a better state of mind and a happier state of himself it might bode better for us as a country," Davison said.

When they found the bodies of Russian troops at an abandoned position, something about the corpses looked wrong.

"There were three or four of their dead. "We did well by not touching them, because when we reached there with a 'kitten', we saw that under them was a PM mine," he said.

The kitten is a folding steel hook that sappers use to dislodge booby traps, nicknamed for its retractable tongs that spring out like cat's claws. The PM is a Soviet-era anti-personnel mine.

"It exploded and blew up both of them, but we stayed safe, thank God."

Occupying Russian troops have sown landmines and booby traps across hundreds of miles of Ukraine's front, a tactic that Kyiv's commanders describe as the primary reason why their long-awaited summer counteroffensive has slowed to a crawl.

SAPPERS GO FIRST

For mine-clearers like Volodymyr, every day brings deadly risk, trying to make the ground safe, first for their fellow soldiers to advance, and eventually for civilians to go home.

"We lose one sapper every day, either wounded or dead. It's a dangerous job. And whether a whole brigade is advancing or around 12 guys go out on their mission, it's always the sappers that go first. It's very dangerous," he said.

The Russians "mine everything. Open doors, boxes and crates, even toys," he said. Even their own dead: "They know that our med-evac groups lift the wounded and the dead, under which they then find these explosives. And this is very dangerous for us."

Landmines inflicted a colossal toll in the first month of the counteroffensive launched in June, said Oleksandr, an anaesthesiologist with the 128 Brigade who treats battlefield wounds at a front-line field hospital.

Since the mines forced commanders to slow the advance, the number of wounded arriving at his hospital has tapered off markedly. But the sappers are still getting killed.

"In this direction, the area is heavily mined and that's why it is being overcome so slowly," he said.

"We had cases when five or six wounded people were brought in, and most of them turned out to be sappers. So, there is such a densely mined area, that even one step away from the already cleared route and this may end rather fatally."

Ukraine's factories have tooled up to make equipment to help keep the sappers safer. In addition to the "kitten" hooks, Volodymyr's unit has been sent "spider boots", which lift each foot off the ground on four metal legs, so any blast they set off will not be triggered directly under a sapper's body.

They are made by Ihor Iefymenko at a factory in Kharkiv, based on a modified Canadian prototype. He told Reuters he pitched the idea to the emergency services after a relative lost a toe to a butterfly mine.

Oleksandr, the medic treating sappers at the front, knows the danger won't end soon.

"There are definitely not enough sappers, and given the intensity of the mining, even after the war the sappers will be one of the main professions," he said.

"We would have liked just to wake up one day as if it were a nightmare, a bad dream and we just shrugged it off, washed with cold water and all of it remained somewhere behind. But this is the reality."

Archaeologists in Serbia are painstakingly brushing sand and soil off the ancient woodwork of a Roman ship discovered by miners in a vast opencast coal quarry.

After an excavator at the Drmno mine uncovered some timber, experts from the site of a nearby former Roman settlement known as Viminacium rushed to try and preserve the skeleton of the ship, the second such discovery in the area since 2020.

The vessel was probably part of a river fleet serving the sprawling and highly-developed Roman city of 45,000 people which had a hippodrome, fortifications, a forum, a palace, temples, amphitheatre, aqueducts, baths and workshops.

Lead archaeologist Miomir Korac said previous findings suggest the ship may date back as far as the 3rd or 4th century AD when Viminacium was capital of the Roman province of Moesia Superior and had a port near a tributary of the Danube River.

"We may assume that this ship is Roman, but we are unsure of its exact age," he told Reuters at the dusty site hanging precariously above a vast open coal pit.

The wood was first sprayed with water and kept under a tarpaulin to prevent decay in the summer heat, Korac added.

Archaeologists believe the two ships and three canoes uncovered so far in the area either sank or were abandoned at the river bank.

The intention is to put the latest discovery on display with thousands of artefacts unearthed from Viminacium near the town of Kostolac, 70 km (45 miles) east of Belgrade.

Mladen Jovicic, who is part of the team working on the newly-discovered ship, said moving its 13-metre hull without breaking it would be tough.

"Our engineer friends ... will prepare a special structure that will be lifted by a crane, and ... the entire process of gradual conservation will follow," he said.

Excavations of Viminacium have been going on since 1882, but archaeologists estimate they have only scoured 5% of the site, which they say is 450 hectares - bigger than New York's Central Park - and unusual in not being buried under a modern city.

Discoveries so far include golden tiles, jade sculptures, mosaics and frescos, weapons, and remains of three mammoths.

West African defence chiefs conclude a two-day meeting on Thursday that is discussing last week's coup in Niger - talks they have promised will send a strong message about their intolerance for unconstitutional takeovers.

The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) has unleashed sanctions , threats of military intervention, and diplomatic overtures in its push to restore the presidency of President Mohamed Bazoum.

It is not clear whether the defence chiefs' meeting in the Nigerian capital Abuja will provide further detail on the bloc's threat to authorise the use of force if coup leaders do not reinstate Bazoum by a Sunday deadline - its strongest stance yet after a string of military takeovers in the region.
